results.headline: When the Teacher Gets High Marks in the Raunchy and the Profane
results.summary_short: Cameron Diaz has found her down-and-dirty element in “Bad Teacher,” a broad comedy that threatens to get ugly and more or less succeeds on that threat.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Teacher

results.headline: A Couple United in Self-Absorption
results.summary_short: “A Love Affair of Sorts” is a critique of what we already know so well: we’re self-absorbed and shallow.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Love Affair of Sorts

results.headline: Drifting Apart, Struggling Together
results.summary_short: “A Better Life,” directed by Chris Weitz, is an emotionally resonant film about a struggle to hold onto a home of one’s own.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Better Life

results.headline: Soaring From Poverty All the Way to Ecstasy
results.summary_short: “Passione” is a documentary in which John Turturro explores the sounds and singers of Naples, Italy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passione

results.headline: Crimes Against Property, as Protests
results.summary_short: “If a Tree Falls: A Story of the Earth Liberation Front” looks at an environmental group that, in 2001, the F.B.I. declared was the country’s “No. 1 domestic terrorist threat.”

results.headline: Captive to Politics and Radical Poetry
results.summary_short: “The High Life,” a drama by the documentarian Zhao Dayong, is the story of a scam artist that turns into a political metaphor.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The High Life

results.headline: Life in the Big House: The Danish Experience
results.summary_short: The Danish drama “R,” set in a maximum-security prison, isn’t the goriest example of its genre, but it is challenging nevertheless.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of R

results.headline: One Man Who Knows the Way of the Horse
results.summary_short: The real-life story of the horse trainer who became an inspiration for the novel and movie “The Horse Whisperer.”

results.headline: In Brooklyn, Pushing Back Against a Redevelopment Plan
results.summary_short: “Battle for Brooklyn,” a documentary by Michael Galinsky and Suki Hawley, chronicles the Atlantic Yards project and the work of a resident who has fought against it.

results.headline: The Sound of (Experimental) Music
results.summary_short: “The Colors of the Prism, the Mechanics of Time,” by Jacqueline Caux, considers Minimalist works and the composers, like Steve Reich and Terry Riley, who write them.

results.headline: Allergic to Homework and Possibly Smitten
results.summary_short: If you can grade on a curve you may find yourself touched, tickled and occasionally surprised by “The Art of Getting By.”

results.headline: A Hyperactive Fly on a Newsroom Wall
results.summary_short: “Page One,” a documentary about The New York Times, is fixated on one particular reporter.

results.summary_short: In “Mr. Popper’s Penguins,” Jim Carrey is a divorced businessman who faces more mayhem after he inherits a gaggle of penguins.

results.headline: A Little Lipstick Soothes Poverty’s Rawness
results.summary_short: In “The Lips” three social workers in the Argentine countryside help villagers confront hardships.

results.headline: 2 Pairs of Sharp Elbows On White Tablecloths
results.summary_short: In “The Trip” Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon motor to fine restaurants in northern England, and along the way they philosophize, joust and parry, and entertain each other, frequently by imitating someone else.
